questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What abnormal finding is demonstrated in the AS-OCT image above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the slit lamp photograph and AS-OCT imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Cystinosis is a rare lysosomal storage disease in which cystine accumulates in organs and tissues throughout the body. AS-OCT in cystinosis shows innumerable hyper-reflective, rod- and needle-like deposits distributed throughout the corneal stroma, corresponding to microscopic cystine crystals (1). This matches the clinical findings seen on slit lamp examination and helps confirm the diagnosis of ocular cystinosis. The crystals accumulate predominantly in the anterior stroma and can cause dysphotopsia (artifacts of light) from scattering of incoming light.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: In addition to corneal findings, how else can ocular cystinosis present in the eye?

answers.answerText: B. Pigmentary retinopathy and crystals in other ocular tissues
answers.explanation: Ocular cystinosis may involve the conjunctiva, iris, ciliary body, lens, retina and optic nerve, each potentially showing crystal deposits (2). Pigmentary retinopathy and optic atrophy may occur in advanced cases of ocular cystinosis.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered in the differential diagnosis for corneal stromal crystals?

answers.explanation: Band keratopathy is due to calcium deposition in Bowman’s and superficial stroma, not crystals; the others are classic crystalline keratopathies (3).

questions.text: Ocular findings of cystinosis are noted in a 30-year-old woman with no history of renal disease and normal renal function. Which form of cystinosis does she most likely have?
questions.title: Question 5

answers.explanation: The clinical presentation described is most consistent with adult/ocular cystinosis. This form of the disorder is characterized by isolated ocular involvement, without the systemic renal impairment that defines the nephropathic forms (infantile and juvenile). With Fanconi syndrome, there are no corneal crystals. The patient's age (30 years old) and the absence of renal disease or Fanconi syndrome are classic for this benign, non-nephropathic variant (4).

questions.title: Question 6
questions.text: Compared with older adults, where does crystal deposition occur in children?

answers.explanation: In children with cystinosis, crystal deposition is most prominent in the anterior corneal stroma (5). This pattern contrasts with older adults, where crystals tend to accumulate more in the posterior stroma due to progressive deposition over time. The anterior localization in children is observable both on slit-lamp examination and anterior segment OCT, where hyperreflective deposits are typically seen closer to the corneal surface in younger patients. Over the years, as new corneal lamellae form and existing ones move posteriorly, crystals are redistributed toward the posterior stroma.

questions.title: Question 7
questions.text: What is the most appropriate topical therapy for this patient?

answers.explanation: Topical cysteamine is the most effective and specific therapy to dissolve and prevent cystine crystal buildup in the cornea; oral cysteamine helps systemic/retinal control (6).

**​Learning Objectives:**

1. Recognize the clinical and imaging features of ocular cystinosis include multicolored refractile stromal deposits on slit-lamp exam and hyperreflective punctate lesions on AS-OCT.
2. Recognize that topical cysteamine is the treatment for reducing corneal crystal burden, whereas systemic cysteamine is useful for systemic symptoms.
